She stopped a few feet from Alistair, her assessment of the bridge complete.

"Dr. Finch," she said. It was not a question. Her voice was a low, even alto, a voice accustomed to the quiet of archives, but it carried an undeniable weight of authority. "Evelyn Reed. Your summons was concise."

"Precision is efficient, Ms. Reed," Alistair replied, his own voice finding a rare and immediate peer. He extended his hand, not in greeting, but to offer her one half of the portable scale. "I assume you have the schematics?" She took the heavy device without a word, her grip firm and practiced. From her satchel, she produced not a flimsy printout, but a heavy, cloth-bound folio of the original bridge blueprints, its pages yellowed and brittle with age. She opened it on the concrete abutment, her finger tracing a load-bearing beam.

"The primary compression members were rated for a maximum distributed load of sixty tons in 1958," she stated, her finger tapping a faded number. "Subsequent reports from '82 and '95 recommended a downgrade to forty-five tons due to galvanic corrosion at the gusset plates. The city council ignored both reports. The official, legally posted limit remains sixty. It is, however, rarely, if ever, enforced." Their eyes met over the ancient blueprints, and in that shared glance, a universe of understanding passed between them. They were two scholars of decay, two surgeons who had studied the same terminal case from different angles.

Their quiet conference was shattered by a deep, grinding rumble. Approaching the bridge from the north was a massive, eighteen-wheel flatbed truck, its engine a guttural roar. It was laden with colossal, curved steel beams, their surfaces gleaming with a fresh coat of Conglom-O-Ape’s signature banana-yellow paint. The truck was a rolling monument to corporate arrogance, its tires bulging under a weight that made the very air seem to tremble. The driver, a large chimpanzee in a greasy vest, had one elbow out the window and was picking at his teeth with a twig, his expression one of bored indifference.

"The patient arrives," Alistair murmured. Without another word, he and Evelyn moved into position. They did not shout or wave their arms. Alistair simply stepped into the center of the lane and raised a hand, a single, calm, authoritative gesture. Evelyn stood slightly behind him, one hand resting on the folio of blueprints, the other holding a small, powerful digital camera. The chimp driver saw Alistair and let out a furious blast from his air horn, a sound meant to scatter any lesser creature from his path. Alistair did not flinch. He did not move. He simply stood there, a small, immovable object of pure procedure. The truck, with a screech of protesting brakes that echoed across the river, shuddered to a halt mere feet from him.

Beside him, Evelyn quietly took a series of high-resolution photographs: the truck, its license plate, the driver’s face, and the clearly visible strain on the vehicle’s tires. The driver’s laughter died, replaced by a low, menacing growl. He was about to restart his engine, to call Alistair’s bluff, when Evelyn spoke, her voice calm and clear.

I have your face, your license, and your cargo on camera. The choice is yours."

The chimpanzee stared at her, his primate brain struggling to process a threat that wasn't physical. He understood fines, but not on this scale. He understood felony charges even less, but the cold certainty in the woman’s voice made them sound terrifyingly real. He looked at the small, quiet man in the overcoat and the severe, watchful woman with the blueprints. They were not screaming. They were not trying to dominate him. They were simply stating facts, laying out a series of consequences as inescapable as a cage. He let out a final, frustrated screech, slammed his fist against his steering wheel, and with a series of grinding, furious gear shifts, began the laborious process of backing his massive truck away from the bridge. Alistair and Evelyn stepped aside, watching as the vehicle, a symbol of corporate might, was forced into a slow, humiliating retreat.

When the truck was gone, a profound silence settled over the bridge once more, broken only by the gentle lapping of the river below. Alistair looked at Evelyn, at the ancient blueprints under her arm and the modern camera in her hand. She had taken his authority and given it teeth, data, and irrefutable leverage. He had found his partner. "A satisfactory initial outcome," he said, the highest form of praise in his lexicon.

Evelyn nodded, her gaze already scanning the road for the next approaching truck. "The procedure has begun, Doctor," she replied. "But this was just a single extraction. The infection is systemic. And it will learn to fight back."

He saw the hope die in the driver’s eyes, replaced by a look of utter defeat. The reporter began speaking into her microphone, her voice filled with manufactured compassion. "In an astonishing display of bureaucratic inflexibility, Commissioner Finch has just denied a critical medical shipment access to the city, holding fast to a rigid interpretation of the law, even with lives potentially on the line…"

Evelyn, however, had already moved to the next step of her own procedure. She stepped up to the driver's window, ignoring the camera completely. "The detour through the southern bypass will add forty-seven minutes to your trip," she said, handing him a printed map on which she had already highlighted the most efficient route. "I have just contacted the bypass toll authority, using the Commissioner’s credentials, and informed them that your vehicle is on emergency civic business. All tolls will be waived. I have also informed St. Swithin’s of your new estimated time of arrival. They are prepared for the delay." Her actions were a whirlwind of cold, practical assistance, a direct counter-narrative to the story of heartless bureaucracy being spun just feet away. She had not broken the rule, but she had mitigated its consequence, robbing the setup of its most potent venom.

The driver, stunned by this unexpected display of ruthless efficiency, could only stammer his thanks before slowly putting his truck in gear and following the new route. The news crew, their story now complicated and far less emotionally clean, looked momentarily flustered. But Alistair knew the damage was already done. The headline would not be "Official Solves Logistical Problem." It would be "Dentist Dictator Blocks Medicine Truck." They had survived the attack, but they had been wounded. As he watched the tail lights of the news van disappear into the city, Alistair looked across the dark, silent river. The silhouette of Mbongo was gone. His work was done. He had found their weakness. It was not the law, and it was not force. It was the messy, unpredictable, and easily manipulated heart of the public itself.
